Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring culturally specific greetings and expressions of politeness

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural protocols in Welcome to Country and Acknowledgement of Country, and the greeting words used by Victorian Aboriginal Peoples

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring how familiarity with a group or individual influences language choices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language can be used for appreciating texts and providing reasons for preferences
Elaboration: Exploring how language is used to appreciate texts using more precise vocabulary, for example ‘I liked how the author described the setting because …’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language can be used for appreciating texts and providing reasons for preferences
Elaboration: Exploring verbs used to express degree of preference, for example ‘liked’, ‘preferred’ and ‘enjoyed’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how different types of texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the typical features of a text, for example a typical introduction to a narrative or the use of dot points in instructions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how different types of texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying that different types of texts might have different forms; for example, an expression of opinion might be in the form of a poster, email or brochure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how different types of texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the organisation and language features in texts such as narratives, recounts, information reports, simple procedures, expression of opinion and responses to texts (including poetry), and discussing their purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Identifying language used to build information across a text, for example by connecting similar and dissimilar things

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Mapping examples of word associations in texts, for example words that refer to the main character in a story, such as ‘Isy’, ‘she’, ‘I’, ‘sister’, ‘student’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Tracking how a person or thing is identified through a section of a text, for example ‘eggs’, ‘they’, ‘them’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Identifying words left out that can be inferred from the surrounding text; for example, in ‘Xanthe went to school. She had a lovely day’, ‘at school’ is inferred

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Using personal and possessive pronouns to link entities previously mentioned in the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Navigate print and digital texts using chapters, tables of contents, indexes, sidebar menus, drop-down menus or links
Elaboration: Recognising how numbered chapters, organisation of tables of contents and alphabetical order of indexes operate to support access to information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Navigate print and digital texts using chapters, tables of contents, indexes, sidebar menus, drop-down menus or links
Elaboration: Exploring how the navigation tools of different websites can be used to locate information

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that connections can be made between ideas by using a compound sentence with 2 or more independent clauses usually linked by a coordinating conjunction
Elaboration: Using coordinating conjunctions (for example, ‘and’, ‘but’ and ‘so’) to construct compound sentences (for example, ‘The wolf huffed / and he puffed / and he blew the house down!’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences, nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Identifying nouns that refer to people, places, concrete objects and ideas in sentences, and identifying the articles and adjectives that extend those nouns

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences, nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Building extended noun groups using articles and adjectives, for example ‘the longest side’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences, nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Building extended verb groups using verbs, for example ‘gently touched’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences, nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Investigating how noun groups can be built up by asking questions about the noun such as ‘How many?’, ‘What’s it like?’ and ‘What type?’, for example ‘two pairs of old walking shoes’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that images and sound add to or multiply the meanings of a text
Elaboration: Identifying images and graphics in a text that add ideas or information not included in the written text, for example a map or table in a factual text or an illustration in a story that gives clues about the setting

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that images and sound add to or multiply the meanings of a text
Elaboration: Identifying visual representations of characters’ actions, reactions, speech and thought processes in narratives, and considering how these images add to or multiply the meaning of accompanying words

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Apply learnt vocabulary and begin to make conscious choices to suit the topic
Elaboration: Selecting vocabulary appropriate to the topic to replace everyday language

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Apply learnt vocabulary and begin to make conscious choices to suit the topic
Elaboration: Discussing new vocabulary encountered in learning area texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Apply learnt vocabulary and begin to make conscious choices to suit the topic
Elaboration: Exploring language used to describe characters in narratives, including nouns (for example, ‘magician’, ‘wizard’ or ‘sorcerer’) and adjectives (for example, ‘gentle’, ‘timid’ or ‘frightened’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Apply learnt vocabulary and begin to make conscious choices to suit the topic
Elaboration: Identifying words from Victorian Aboriginal languages relevant to a topic

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that capital letters are used in titles and commas are used to separate items in lists
Elaboration: Identifying how capital letters are used in the titles of texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that capital letters are used in titles and commas are used to separate items in lists
Elaboration: Identifying commas used in lists in a variety of types of texts, for example ‘This class has students who speak Vietnamese, Thai and Arabic at home.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literary texts created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Recognising recurring characters in particular settings in texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literary texts created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the way that a wide range of Australian authors and illustrators depict the Australian outback and the associated characters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literary texts created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing the depiction of characters in particular settings in well-known fairytales from a wide range of world authors, for example children in forests, and royalty in castles and towers

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Compare features of a range of literary texts, such as characters and settings, and share personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing preferences for stories set in familiar or unfamiliar worlds, or about characters whose lives are like or unlike their own

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Compare features of a range of literary texts, such as characters and settings, and share personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing their feelings about the positive and negative behaviours of non-human characters, such as animals

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the plots, characters and settings of a range of literary texts and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Comparing how similar characters or settings are described in texts from different contexts, for example how the seasons are described

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the plots, characters and settings of a range of literary texts and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Identifying and comparing verb groups used to convey actions, emotions and dialogue in a range of literary texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the plots, characters and settings of a range of literary texts and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Identifying the language used to describe the landscape in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander stories

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify, reproduce and experiment with rhythmic sound and word patterns in poems, chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Exploring poems, chants, rhymes or songs from different home languages of class members

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts by adapting structures and language features of previously encountered literary texts through writing, drawing and performance
Elaboration: Inventing some speech, dialogue or behaviour for a favourite character, which may include the use of video and audio tools, for an alternative event or outcome to the one in the original text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics and texts, actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending their own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements, and giving instructions
Elaboration: Exploring ways to comment on what others say, including using sentence starters such as ‘I like the way you …’, ‘I agree that …’, ‘I have a different thought …’, and ‘I’d like to say something different …’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics and texts, actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending their own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements, and giving instructions
Elaboration: Demonstrating appropriate listening behaviours, responding to and paraphrasing a partner’s contribution to a discussion, for example in think-pair-share activities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics and texts, actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending their own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements, and giving instructions
Elaboration: Asking relevant questions and making connections with personal experiences and the contributions of others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics and texts, actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending their own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements, and giving instructions
Elaboration: Understanding how to disagree or respectfully offer an alternative

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Preparing and delivering oral presentations using more formal language and specific vocabulary about content area topics

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver short spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Adjusting volume and tone when speaking in more formal situations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of blending, segmenting and manipulating to read and write increasingly complex words (phonemic awareness)
Elaboration: Blending and segmenting sounds in words, for example ‘b-r-o-th-er’ or ‘c-l-ou-d-y’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of blending, segmenting and manipulating to read and write increasingly complex words (phonemic awareness)
Elaboration: Deleting and substituting sounds (phonemes) in spoken words to form new words (for example, deleting the initial ‘scr’ in ‘scratch’ and substituting new initial sounds to form words such as ‘catch’, ‘batch’ and ‘hatch’) and substituting a medial sound to form a new word (for example, ‘stack’ becomes ‘stick’)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme–grapheme correspondence knowledge to read and write words of one or more syllables with vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant blends and silent letters (phonic knowledge)
Elaboration: Reading words with digraphs where one letter is not pronounced (for example, ‘knife’ and ‘thumb’) and using them in writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme–grapheme correspondence knowledge to read and write words of one or more syllables with vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant blends and silent letters (phonic knowledge)
Elaboration: Providing the sounds for less common sound–letter matches (for example, ‘ight’) and using them in writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme–grapheme correspondence knowledge to read and write words of one or more syllables with vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant blends and silent letters (phonic knowledge)
Elaboration: Reading words with vowel digraphs (‘ee’, ‘oo’, ‘ai’, ‘ay’ and ‘ea’)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to read and write words whose spelling is not completely predictable from their sounds, including high-frequency words
Elaboration: Using known words and knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to write unknown words, for example ‘one’, ‘once’, ‘only’ and ‘lone’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to read and write words whose spelling is not completely predictable from their sounds, including high-frequency words
Elaboration: Using context to read the correct word when an unknown word has more than one plausible pronunciation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build morphemic word families using knowledge of prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Using morphemic knowledge of words to spell unknown words, for example ‘one’, ‘once’, ‘cover’, ‘covering’ and ‘uncover’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build morphemic word families using knowledge of prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Writing unknown words using morphemic knowledge; for example, using the known word ‘friend’ to write ‘friendly’ and ‘friendship’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts with phrasing and fluency, using phonic and word knowledge, and make and monitor meaning by re-reading and self-correcting
Elaboration: Using phonic (sound–letter) and morphemic knowledge, and knowledge of high-frequency words when decoding text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts with phrasing and fluency, using phonic and word knowledge, and make and monitor meaning by re-reading and self-correcting
Elaboration: Monitoring their own reading, self-correcting or reading back, and re-reading when meaning does not make sense

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how similar topics and information are presented in different types of texts
Elaboration: Reading a poem, narrative and informative text about life cycles and discussing what is learnt

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how similar topics and information are presented in different types of texts
Elaboration: Exploring recipes presented on food packets, in recipe books, in short video clips and in a digital form, noting their shared purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of different types of texts
Elaboration: Identifying the audience of advertisements and signs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Listening for specific information and providing key facts or points from an informative or persuasive text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Listening and responding to detailed instructions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Integrating information from print, images and prior knowledge to make supportable inferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Identifying the main idea of a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Predicting vocabulary that is likely to be in a text, based on the topic and the purpose of the text; for example, predicting that ‘station’ and ‘arrive’ would be in a text recounting a train journey

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Using prior knowledge to make and confirm predictions when reading a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and begin to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context and text structures to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Using graphic organisers to represent the connections between characters, order of events or sequence of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative, informative and persuasive texts for familiar audiences using simple text structures, topic-specific vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Creating texts so that readers and/or audiences follow the sequence of ideas or events, using vocabulary (including topic-specific vocabulary) appropriate for the purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative, informative and persuasive texts for familiar audiences using simple text structures, topic-specific vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using digital tools to create texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short narrative, informative and persuasive texts for familiar audiences using simple text structures, topic-specific vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using simple and compound sentences correctly and flexibly to express and combine ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for spelling, sentence boundary punctuation and text structure
Elaboration: Reviewing and developing sentences; for example, adding prepositional phrases such as ‘with a long tail’ to improve descriptions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for spelling, sentence boundary punctuation and text structure
Elaboration: Editing by adding, deleting or changing vocabulary to improve a text; for example, replacing an everyday noun with a topic-specific one

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for spelling, sentence boundary punctuation and text structure
Elaboration: Reviewing sentences for grammatical accuracy, for example use of pronouns

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words legibly and with growing fluency using unjoined lower-case and upper-case letters
Elaboration: Consolidating a functional pencil grip/grasp
